title: R43887
content: The Older Americans Act (OAA), enacted in 1965, provides social services and programs for individuals aged 60 and older. Services include nutrition programs, caregiver support, employment services, and programs to prevent abuse. Most programs are administered by the Administration on Aging (AOA) within the Department of Health and Human Services, except for Title V which is administered by the Department of Labor. Title V, Community Service Employment for Older Americans (CSEOA), is administered by the Department of Labor's Employment and Training Administration. Congress has reauthorized the Older Americans Act (OAA) multiple times, with the last reauthorization in 2006 authorizing appropriations through FY2011. The Older Americans Act (OAA) has been reauthorized and amended by Congress multiple times. The last reauthorization in 2006 extended authorizations of appropriations through FY2011. Despite the expiration of authorizations, funding for OAA programs has continued. This report discusses OAA funding, including an overview of FY2015 funding, a breakdown of current-year funding for programs, funding history since FY2001, legislative activity in FY2015, and funding decisions for selected programs. The report provides an overview of OAA's FY2015 funding, including a breakdown of current-year funding for programs, funding history since FY2001, legislative activity in FY2015, and funding decisions for selected programs. Appendixes offer more detailed funding information and history. For background on DOL and HHS appropriations, refer to CRS Report R43236. For more on the Older Americans Act, see CRS Report R43414. The FY2015 Consolidated and Further Continuing Appropriations Act (P.L. 113-235) funded OAA programs at $1.878 billion, a slight increase from FY2014. Title III programs received the largest share of funding, with 70.7% allocated to nutrition, supportive services, family caregivers, and health promotion activities. Title V, the CSEOA Program, received 23.1% of the funding. Title III programs under the OAA received the largest proportion of funding, with 70.7% allocated to various activities. Title V, the CSEOA Program, received 23.1% of the funding. The remaining funds were allocated to other AOA-administered activities under different titles. Two exceptions in FY2015 funding included support for Holocaust survivors and an Elder Justice Initiative under Title IV. In FY2015, most OAA programs had the same funding as FY2014, except for two exceptions. Aging Network Support Activities received $2.5 million for Holocaust survivors, and Elder Rights Support Activities received $4.0 million for an Elder Justice Initiative. Total discretionary funding for OAA programs increased slightly from FY2001 to FY2002, remained flat through FY2006, then increased annually from FY2006 to FY2010. Funding levels have since remained below FY2010 levels. Total discretionary funding for OAA programs increased slightly from FY2001 to FY2002, remained flat through FY2006, then increased annually from FY2006 to FY2010. Funding levels have since remained below FY2010 levels, with a decline in FY2011 through FY2013, mostly due to sequestration. Total discretionary funding for the CSEOA Program to assist low-income seniors decreased from FY2011 to FY2013, primarily due to sequestration. Funding in FY2013 fell below the FY2007 level. However, funding for OAA programs increased in FY2014 and FY2015, with President Obama signing the Consolidated and Further Continuing Appropriations Act, 2015 to provide $1.878 billion in FY2015 funding. President Obama signed the Consolidated and Further Continuing Appropriations Act, 2015 (P.L. 113-235) on December 16, 2014, providing $1.878 billion in FY2015 funding for OAA programs and activities. The FY2015 appropriations law reflected the new consolidated ACL account structure, rather than the previous AOA account structure. The White House Conferences on Aging have historically focused attention on older individuals' concerns and provided guidance to policymakers. The President's FY2015 budget proposed $3.0 million for a White House Conference on Aging in 2015, but the Senate bill did not allocate dedicated funding for it. The first White House Conference on Aging was held in 1961, with subsequent conferences in 1971, 1981, 1995, and 2005. The President's FY2015 budget proposed $3.0 million for a conference in 2015, but no dedicated funding was provided in the final FY2015 appropriations. The White House plans to hold the conference in 2015 in Washington, DC, with scaled-down scope due to lack of direct appropriations. The White House Conference on Aging in 2015 did not receive specified funding and no dedicated funding was provided in the final FY2015 appropriations. The conference will focus on retirement security, healthy aging, long-term services and supports, and elder justice, recognizing the anniversaries of Social Security, Medicare, Medicaid, and the Older Americans Act.
